messageBody:
Well, I just tried this myself, and I had to do one additional step:

Implement all protected methods from Class A in Class B (Which is an inner
class)
1. For every protected method , call super.<method Name>;
2. For Constructors, call super(<same parameters as parent constructor>);

Thanks,
-Kamal.

-----Original Message-----
From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of
Kamal Ahmed
Sent: Friday, March 10, 2006 4:02 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [junit] Testing Abstract Classes

Hi,

I found a way to test abstract classes:



* Class A = Abstract Class to be tested



* Declare a Class C which extends TestCase



* In Class C Declare an inner class B which is static and extends class A,
and which implements the unimplemented methods of class A.



Now you have access to all the protected and public methods declared in
Class A.



I know this is also described in the book JUnit Recipes, by J.B Rainsburger,
Page 48, Chapter 2:



1. Select one of the implementations test cases (not sure what that
means, does it mean to choose an abstract class?)
2. Create a new abstract test case class that stores the tests for the
intended behavior (don't we just have to declare the minimum contract
methods, with "do nothing"?)
3. Change the implementations test case so it extends the new abstract
test case (in my case the test case extends TestCase class)
4. For each implementation test that verifies only interface-scope
behavior. Identify each place where an instance of the implementation is
created (did not understand this)
5. Inside the test case. Find the code that creates the object under
test. Move this code into a separate creation method, but store the
instantiated object in a reference to the interface, and not the
implementation. (I would need an example just for this)
6. Repeat until the test has no more direct references to the
implementation by it's class name.
7. Create an abstract method in the abstract test case for each
creation method you extracted (would this be required in case of an inner
class)
8. Now that the test refers only to the interface and other methods in
the abstract test case, move the test up into the abstract test case.
9. repeat all steps for each implementation test case, until the only
tests remaining in the implementation test cases verify
implementation-specific behavior (did not quite understand this one)



Since I did not follow completely what the recipe was, are these two
approaches same?



Thanks,

-Kamal.
